speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, we've been using "I would like," which is very useful, but of course you're going to want to sometimes ask someone else what it is they would like or what it is they would want. So let's move on and start asking someone else what, what they want. You may already be familiar with the way to say "do you want" in French, which is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: There's a few songs that have it in. If you've heard Abba [laughs], you may, you may be familiar with it. There's also some other people who use t- that term.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Um, how would you say, "Do you want to reserve a table?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, simply th- there are those I-O-N words like "visitation" in English, where you cut off the "-ation," you add E-R, and you have "to visit."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I would like to visit the park?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "Do you want to visit the park?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How about, "I would like to visit the Louvre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "Do you want to visit the Louvre?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I would like to know?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The word for "if" in French is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I would like to know if it's romantic"? So from the beginning. "I would like to know."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, so the word for "if" is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And the word for "it is," is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So you can see they sound a bit similar, but you'll get used to them as we go on. So again, "if" is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The "if" sounds a bit more like the "C" that you would swim in, a little bit like that, but shorter. And the "it is" sounds a bit more like the English word "say," but it's not pronounced as clearly as that.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: But that's the difference, one veers more towards "C" and the other towards "say." But again, there are no exact equivalents because it's a different language.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So again, one more time, "if" is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Let's move onto another word now. The word for "but" in French is...

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I would like a room for two people for two nights, but I'd like to know if it's romantic"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: We'll start at the beginning so that you can remember it all.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Um, start with, "I would like a room."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "I would like to know if it's romantic."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now put the whole thing together. "I would like a room for two people, for two nights, but I'd like to know if it's romantic."

speaker: Marion
text: "Je voudrais une chambre pour deux personnes, pour deux nuits, mais je voudrais savoir si c'est romantique."

speaker: Narrator
text: This is the end of CD 1.
